game.bin.levels.load

Class XMLLevelLoader

  • java.lang.Object
    • bin.levels.XMLLevelLoader

  • public class XMLLevelLoader
extends java.lang.Object
    Level loader for Plates game. All levels are stored in .xml files. Here's structure of this file: 
    
 <levels pack-name="some name here">
     <level identifier="name of level">
         <cells>
             <column>
                 <cell type="start" />
                 <cell type="empty" />
             </column>
             <column>
                 <cell type="empty" />
                 <cell type="finish" />
             </column>
         </cells>
     </level>
 </levels>
    Levels stored in level packages, level packs stored in files. So, to make own level, you must create pack for this level. That's caused by two things:
    1. I don't want to store single levels in packs,
    2. If they'll stored in multiple files - there'll be more time for loading.
    This class has some functions, and it's instance as static field. That's because to load .xml file using Java, you need to use some classes (DocumentBuilder, XPathFactory and XPath), and I didn't want to initialize them in each call of load method (some of this constructors can throw exception). And, I don't like using this construction: 
    
 public class SomeClass {
     private static String someStaticField;

     {
         someStaticField = "field";
     }

     public static void foo() {
         System.out.println(someStaticField);
     }
 }
    So, my first solution was to make function setup(): 
    
 public class SomeClass {
     private static String someStaticField;

     public static void setup() {
         someStaticField = "field";
     }

     public static void foo() {
         System.out.println(someStaticField);
     }
 }
    And call it in the Main class. But, I've found better solution for me. I have private instance of class, and private constructor. All initializing run in it.
    Since:
    Plates v. 1.0
    Author:
    Dmitriy Meleshko

    • Method Detail

      • loadLevel

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.util.ArrayList<LevelCell>> loadLevel(java.lang.String path,
                                                                            java.lang.String levelName)
                                                                     throws java.io.IOException,
                                                                            org.xml.sax.SAXException,
                                                                            javax.xml.xpath.XPathExpressionException
        Function for loading level.
        Parameters:
        path - path to file. Note: it's URI, not URL!
        levelName - name of level. See structure of file: all levels have name
        Returns:
        2D grid of level cells It's ArrayList<ArrayList<String>> because it's easier to operate with ArrayList than with Array.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        org.xml.sax.SAXException
        javax.xml.xpath.XPathExpressionException
        See Also:
        loadLevel(URL, String), innerLoadLevel(String, String)

      • innerLoadLevel

        private java.util.ArrayList<java.util.ArrayList<LevelCell>> innerLoadLevel(java.lang.String path,
                                                                           java.lang.String levelName)
                                                                    throws java.io.IOException,
                                                                           org.xml.sax.SAXException,
                                                                           javax.xml.xpath.XPathExpressionException
        Method for loading levels. loadLevel(String, String) and loadLevel(URL, String) just call This method of private instance.
        Parameters:
        path - path to file. Note: it's URL, not URI!
        levelName - name of level. See structure of file: all levels have name
        Returns:
        2D grid of level cells. It's ArrayList<ArrayList<String>> because it's easier to operate with ArrayList than with Array.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        org.xml.sax.SAXException
        javax.xml.xpath.XPathExpressionException
